review_title: Students and employees are the least priority
job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Vancouver, BC
pros: Reasonable workload in most positions
cons: The company appears to be lacking in employee-focused leadership. The current management team has been criticized for creating a sort of exclusive "boys' club" that does not benefit the majority of students and staff. The inattention to these critical groups is evident in the president's emphasis on his personal agenda. It is disappointing that a president, who should be elevating his team by providing professional development opportunities, appears to have lost his way in helping the community thrive. The pay is lower than comparable schools, turnover is high, and professional growth is limited. As such, this school should only be considered as a last option for prospective employees. Finally, it is regrettable that the on-campus food does not meet basic nutritional standards.

review_title: Good place to work although somewhat disorganized and challenging for new employees
job_title: Student Success Facilitator in North Vancouver, BC
pros: There is a positive work culture and staff care about the students. In my role I'm able to innovate in creating programming for students, which is rewarding. Beautiful campus to work at. Great benefits through the union and pay is fairly good for the role.
cons: Even though it's a small university, the departments are very disconnected and unaware of what the others are doing. This leads to confusion and some departments being territorial about projects instead of collaborative. This disconnect was even more difficult when we started working remotely in March 2020. There's lots of staff turnover and since there's only a few employees in each department, it really impacts workflow and staff have to double up on work. During onboarding training is limited so when I was a new employee it took me a long time to understand my role. It made me really dislike my job for the first 6 months and I almost left, but things improved.

job_title: Professor in North Vancouver, BC
pros: Colleagues are second to none. Lovely campus. Extended medical is superb!
cons: Capilano has a lower salary than a UBC professor in the same job with less experience than I have. Have to pay for parking. No compensation for research or publishing work. The cost of living in Vancouver is insane. Even though it is an excellent salary (6 figures after a few years in my experience level), professors are still struggling and can not afford to purchase a home.

job_title: Campus Planner in North Vancouver, BC
pros: Great work-life balance, and healthy work environment. Nice campus.
cons: Pay and benefits are not competitive.

job_title: University Instructor in North Vancouver, BC
pros: Interesting colleagues, reasonable office and instructional space, gorgeous campus, a nice mix of international and domestic students, some flexibility in scheduling.  Lots of freedom in many areas in pedagogy, text choice, and course design. Depending on the subject and department, faculty can have freedom in course content, text choice, pedagogy, and design.
cons: secretive  management that remains in a perpetual  crisis mode, constant demands for volunteer work at the institution doing everything from weeding to endless night sessions for orientation, and far too many meetings. IT is not well supported, faculty pay high costs to park-unlike staff employees-and  the program mix limits student choices-no computer sciences, no fine arts, and limited . Takes a long time for faculty to get permanent jobs and a bizarre set of evaluations/ student ratings play a decisive role in continued appointment.  There is no tenure.  Despite the talk, the student experience in various programmes is increasingly narrow with all courses taught by faculty in the program specialty, and all enrollment limited to program students.  The isolation and divisions is unhealthy for student learning and limits innovation/ faculty interaction.

job_title: Instructor in Vancouver, BC

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Vancouver, BC
pros:
I realize that not every person in an organization can be happy, and higher up the food chain is no different. However, I love being part of the CapU community, it's like a family and support network at work. We have some long serving employees, and people stay because of the community spirit, and the drive to make our students successful. 

Work-life balance is amazing here. My line manager is all about looking after ourselves. Work hard but rest well. Benefits are the best I've ever had. Wages are set by ministry but the benefits and work-life balance more than make up for that. 

I feel very lucky to work here at this beautiful campus with such wonderful colleagues and friends. 

We are celebrating our 50th birthday this year (2018/2019) and I'm so happy to be here to experience the fun and the events. I look forward to seeing how Cap grows in the next 50 years.
cons: We are starting to put into place new policies and procedures to help us build on our successes, however this will take time. Change can be frightening for some, we need to recognize that and support that.

review_title: Exciting Changes - Great Place to Work
job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Vancouver, BC
pros: The people here are amazing, I have found it to be very inclusive and supportive. Amazing benefits and pension package and lots of opportunity for professional development which I have enjoyed taking advantage of. Work - life balance is great, hours are great and have been flexible to suit my family needs. Lots of focus on wellness of staff. Many projects on the go and lots of opportunities to get involved across campus with committees etc. The leaders are very down to earth and have a door open style. They also keep us well informed with what is going on at a higher level.
cons: Many projects on the go, sometimes too many things to do and not enough time to get them all done. Pay is not fantastic, but benefits package do make a big difference.

review_title: Transition #1 done, more change & results coming
job_title: Manager in North Vancouver, BC
pros:
Every department has a few core, loyal, hard working and cooperative people
Rainforest work environment is gorgeous every day. 
Incremental improvements have upped our game.
Great big improvements (academic & administrative) are just around the corner.
Small campus means students come first.
Lots of freedom for employees to experiment and try new things (but expect do-it-yourself)
cons:
Construction on Hwy #1 makes the commute a little rough...
Trans link connection needs incremental improvement and then some...
The food is just above cafeteria grade (bring your lunch!).
There are some growing pains including off-the-edge of the desk work requirements ,,, but with change, comes opportunity.
